title: Interventions to prevent obesity in children aged 5 to 11 years old

I can help you transform the Cochrane abstract into a Plain Language Summary (PLS) following Cochrane guidelines.

Here is the transformed summary:

**What are the benefits and risks of interventions to prevent obesity in children aged 5 to 11 years old?**

**Key Messages:**

* Interventions that aim to prevent obesity in children may have a modest beneficial effect on obesity in childhood at short- and medium-term, but not at long-term follow-up.
* Dietary interventions alone may result in little to no difference.
* Limited evidence of low quality was identified on the effect of dietary and/or activity interventions on severe adverse events and health inequalities.
* There is a dearth of evidence for home and community-based settings, for children living with disabilities, and indicators of health inequities.

**Introduction to the review topic and review aims:**

**What is obesity in children?**

Obesity is a serious health problem in children. It can affect their development, health, and well-being. Interventions that aim to prevent obesity involve behavioural change strategies that promote healthy eating or "activity" levels (physical activity, sedentary behaviour and/or sleep) or both.

**What did we want to find out?**

We wanted to find out: which types of interventions work best to prevent obesity in children; the effects of dietary and/or activity interventions on changes in BMI, zBMI score, and serious adverse events.

**What did we do?**

We searched for studies that compared interventions to prevent obesity in children with no intervention, usual care, or with another eligible intervention. We included studies that measured outcomes at a minimum of 12 weeks post baseline.

**What did we find?**

This review includes 172 studies (189,707 participants). The main setting for intervention delivery was schools (111 studies), followed by the community (15 studies), the home (eight studies) and a clinical setting (seven studies). Eighty-six interventions were implemented for less than nine months.

**Dietary interventions versus control:**

Dietary interventions, compared with control, may have little to no effect on BMI at short-term follow-up and at medium-term follow-up. Dietary interventions, compared with control, probably have little to no effect on BMI at long-term follow-up.

**Activity interventions versus control:**

Activity interventions, compared with control, may have little to no effect on BMI and zBMI at short-term or long-term follow-up. Activity interventions likely result in a slight reduction of BMI and zBMI at medium-term follow-up.

**Dietary and activity interventions versus control:**

Dietary and activity interventions, compared with control, may result in a slight reduction in BMI and zBMI at short-term follow-up and likely result in a reduction of BMI and zBMI at medium-term follow-up.

**What are the limitations of the evidence?**

The body of evidence in this review demonstrates that a range of school-based "activity" interventions, alone or in combination with dietary interventions, may have a modest beneficial effect on obesity in childhood at short- and medium-term, but not at long-term follow-up. Dietary interventions alone may result in little to no difference. Limited evidence of low quality was identified on the effect of dietary and/or activity interventions on severe adverse events and health inequalities.

**How up to date is this evidence?**

The evidence is up to date to February 2023.
